data.text: Contents
Infection control risks associated with mattresses/pillows and zipped seat cushions ... 6
Introduction
The poor care and maintenance of mattress covers and foam has been recognised for many years as a serious risk to the patient in relation to infection prevention and tissue viability.

The integrity of the mattress cover ensures that fluids such as blood and body fluids cannot seep through to the foam where micro-organisms can be harboured and be a potential cause of cross infection between patients.

Foam has a relatively short life span (4-5 years).If used after the foam has fatigued the patient can sink through the foam, therefore being supported by the bedframe rather than the foam mattresses. This results in significantly higher interface pressure for patients and a higher risk of pressure damage.

The checking of mattresses is required to comply with Care Quality Commission requirements under the Hygiene Code and the regulatory framework: ensuring there are systems in place to protect patients, staff and visitors from health care associated infections; and that all reusable equipment is properly decontaminated prior to use.
Purpose
The purpose of this policy is to:
To ensure a robust process exists to protect patients from the risk of infection due to damaged or contaminated mattresses
To provide advice on the cleaning and maintenance of all mattresses and pillows
To ensure that these items are replaced as soon as they become unsafe due to contamination
To ensure adequate provision of replacement items.
Definitions

table_items.text: Presence or the reasonably anticipated presence of blood or other potentially infectious materials on an item or surface.
Mattress that is no longer fit for purpose due to strikethrough / staining of the foam, the foam being wet or bottoming out of the foam, whereby the bed base can be felt through the foam
Staining of the cover and foam
This term refers to all support surfaces which are operated mechanically by electricity or battery. These include all alternating pressure mattresses, or low air loss systems, dynamic and trolleys.

The Static Foam Pressure Mattress closely follows the contours of parts of the body where there is direct contact with the supporting surface and thereby redistributes pressure over a large surface area.

data.text: Duties

Site Infection Prevention and Control Committee's (IPCC's) is responsible for the review of this policy at least every two years, but more frequently if there are changes to Infection Prevention and Control Legislation or guidance.
The Chief Executive has overall responsibility for:

Ensuring the Trust has the necessary management systems in place to enable the effective implementation of this policy and overall responsibility for the health and safety of staff, patients and visitors.
The Director for Infection Prevention and Control (DIPC) will have operational responsibility for the effective implementation of this policy.
Head Nurse Infection Prevention and Control

Will give advice against this policy and ensure that all staff have access to this policy via the Trust Intranet and ensure that it is updated every two years or in line with current national guidance
Matrons are responsible for:
Ensuring all staff are aware of this policy AND ensuring that staff are aware of their responsibilities. Work in partnership with the IPCT and MEMS.
Bed Cleaning Team are responsible for
The appropriate cleaning / decontamination of mattresses in between patient use within the bed cleaning operational hours /scope

Responsible for condemning any mattresses identified during their tasks in their clinical areas during bed cleaning operational hours /scope (if the mattress cover is stained / torn /soiled or the mattress is no longer fit for purpose)
To notify ward staff when mattress has been condemned so that they can arrange disposal and request a replacement
Nursing staff (including Allied Health Professionals) who undertake bed cleaning duties are responsible for:
The appropriate cleaning / decontamination of mattresses in between patient use outside of bed cleaning operational scope / hours

All ward/department staff are responsible for condemning any mattresses in their clinical area identified outside of the bed cleaning operational hours / scope (if the mattress cover is stained / torn /soiled or the mattress is no longer fit for purpose)
Follow correct process for disposal of mattresses as laid out in this policy (section 8)
Infection Prevention and Tissue Viability Teams Responsible for:
Advising on decontamination issues, approving condemnation of mattresses and the coordination of the training of staff
Medical Equipment Library Responsible for:
Storage and issuing of Specialist mattresses
Arranging appropriate / decontamination of specialist mattresses not fit for purpose
Providing wards and departments with clear mattress bags for storing and transporting of used specialist mattresses
Porters
Delivery and collection of mattresses as required.
Infection control risks associated with mattresses/pillows and
zipped seat cushions
All types of bed mattresses are classed as medical devices (MDA/2010/002, Medical Devices Alert).

Damage to mattress covers, pillows and seat cushions can allow blood or body fluids to pass through and contaminate the inner core. There is a risk of potential cross-infection if contaminated items remain in use.
They can become damaged at any time during use or storage, for example from:
Needlestick;
Strike-through;
Damage from sharp objects;
Abrasion during handling;
Transport or movement;
Inappropriate cleaning and decontamination processes.
Static foam based mattresses
Cleaning Static Foam Mattresses
6.1.1  Following discharge and after each patient use all mattresses should be cleaned using the following methods:
Disposable gloves and aprons should be worn if splashing could occur, eye/face protection should be worn
Using Clinell Universal Wipes clean both sides of the mattress; wipe plastic pillowcases and whole bed frame
Mattresses MUST be thoroughly dry prior to remaking the bed as moisture will create an environment for micro-organisms to multiply and will destroy the mattress cover

If a room / bed space is to be terminally cleaned, leave the mattress without bed linen so that it can be cleaned as part of the terminal clean process. Within operational hours and scope of bed cleaning team, all terminal cleans need to be requested through Teletracking system. Out of hours / scope this needs to be carried out by appropriately trained domestic staff

Prior to remaking the bed inspect the inner and outer services of the cover and the zip fasteners. Unzip the mattress and inspect the foam core for visible soiling. If the core mattress is wet or stained, the mattress should be withdrawn from service and condemned
When cleaning is complete, remove apron and gloves and dispose of in clinical waste. On removal of gloves, hands should be washed using soap and water
Bed frames must be cleaned between each patient using a Clinell Universal
Wipe
Specialist mattresses
Cleaning specialist mattresses
Nursing staff are responsible for the cleaning/ decontamination of specialist mattresses

7.2.1 For dynamic pressure relieving mattresses, both overlays and replacement systems, clean with Clinell Universal Wipes and allow to dry thoroughly before remaking bed or returning the mattress to the Medical Equipment Library
7.2.2 Deflate fully and roll mattress, keeping pump separate
7.2.3 Place in a large clear bag supplied by Medical Equipment Library prior to returning to the Medical Equipment Library
7.2.4 The enclosed Trust Decontamination Certificate MUST be completed and clearly visible (Appendix 1)
Pillows
7.3.1 Pillows must have a fluid resistant cover
7.3.2 Pillows must be inspected for signs of damage and/or soiling in between patient use
7.3.3 They must be cleaned in between patients using Clinell Universal wipes
7.3.4 If the cover is torn / damaged, the pillow must be condemned and disposed of as clinical waste
Cots/ resusitaires
7.4.1  These should be washed with Clinell Universal Wipes or the Trust approved disinfectant solution following the above procedure.
Patient trolleys
Full clean after each using Clinell Universal Wipes. If the trolley mattress is stained/damaged it needs to be withdrawn from service and condemned.
Condemning, disposal and replacement of mattresses
Condemning
If a mattress is found to be stained, torn, the foam core is visibly soiled or heavily indented then the mattress must be deemed unfit for purpose and condemned.
Disposal

9.2.1 Condemned static foam mattresses should be cleaned thoroughly using Clinell Universal Wipes. (Broomfield site mattress are to then to be placed a blue plastic bag ready for collection from the ward)

9.2.2 Request is to be made via Teletracking (item request) for disposal by the Porters from wards and departments. This will include the origin being the area with the mattress to be removed and destination which will be mattress store
9.2.3 The mattress must be clearly labelled as ‘faulty/condemned or ‘do not use' so porters are aware of correct segregation
9.2.4 Mattresses MUST NOT be left in waste disposal store rooms, or abandoned in corridors

9.2.5 All ward/department staff are responsible for condemning any mattresses in their clinical area identified outside of the bed cleaning operational hours /scope (if the mattress cover is stained / torn /soiled or the mattress is no longer fit for purpose)
9.2.6 Follow correct process for disposal of mattresses as laid out in this policy (section 8)
Replacement
9.3.1 The Porters will replace static foam mattresses when the condemned mattress is removed.
9.3.2 Replacement of specialised mattresses must be managed by the individual ward/department in conjunction with MEMS
Training requirements

All Trust staff to undertake Mandatory Infection Prevention and Control updates The IPCT has primary responsibility for providing training on the policy where needed. Managers have the responsibly to support the IPCT by ensuring that staff are able to attend training sessions in response to identified needs

data.text: Approval and implementation

All policies, procedures and guidelines will be approved by the Site Infection Control Committee which are the specialist groups with the authority to approve local policies and guidelines. These will then be forwarded to the Document control team for submission and ratification by the Joint Document Management Group.
It is the author's responsibility to inform the Director Harm Free Care of the approved policy documents when they are uploaded to the Trust's Intranets.
